t: Job 28
Job’s Discourse on Wisdom
“Surely*pn there is a mine for silver, And*ld a place where*i gold is refined.
Iron*ld is taken from the earth, And*ld copper is*i smelted from*i ore.
Man*ild puts an end to darkness, And*ld searches every recess For*ld ore in the darkness and the shadow of death.
He*ld breaks open a shaft away from people; In*ild places*i forgotten by feet They*ld hang far away from men; They*ld swing to and fro.
As*ild for*i the earth, from it comes bread, But*ld underneath it is turned up as by fire;
Its*ld stones are*i the source of sapphires, And*ld it contains gold dust.
That*ild path no bird knows, Nor*ld has the falcon’s eye seen it.
The*ld proud lions have not trodden it, Nor*ld has the fierce lion passed over it.
He*ld puts his hand on the flint; He*ld overturns the mountains at the roots.
He*ld cuts out channels in the rocks, And*ld his eye sees every precious thing.
He*ld dams up the streams from trickling; What*ild is*i hidden he brings forth to light.
“But*ln where can wisdom be found? And*ld where is*i the place of understanding?
Man*ld does not know its value, Nor*ld is it found in the land of the living.
The*ld deep says, ‘It*i is*i not in me’; And*ld the sea says, ‘It*i is*i not with me.’
It*ld cannot be purchased for gold, Nor*ld can silver be weighed for*i its price.
It*ld cannot be valued in the gold of Ophir, In*ld precious onyx or sapphire.
Neither*ld gold nor crystal can equal it, Nor*ld can it be exchanged for jewelry of fine gold.
No*ld mention shall be made of coral or quartz, For*ld the price of wisdom is*i above rubies.
The*ld topaz of Ethiopia cannot equal it, Nor*ld can it be valued in pure gold.
“From*ln where then does wisdom come? And*ld where is*i the place of understanding?
It*ld is hidden from the eyes of all living, And*ld concealed from the birds of the air.
Destruction*ld and Death say, ‘We*ld have heard a report about it with our ears.’
God*ld understands its way, And*ld He knows its place.
For*ld He looks to the ends of the earth, And*ild sees under the whole heavens,
To*ld establish a weight for the wind, And*ld apportion the waters by measure.
When*ld He made a law for the rain, And*ld a path for the thunderbolt,
Then*ld He saw wisdom*i and declared it; He*ld prepared it, indeed, He searched it out.
And*ld to man He said, ‘Behold,*ld the fear of the Lord, that is*i wisdom, And*ld to depart from evil is*i understanding.’”
